facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 158 of 1960 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 158 of 1960. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated July 1, 1960, of the Calcutta High Court in Cr. Revision No. 500 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated July 1, 1960, of the Calcutta High Court in Cr. Revision No. 500 of 1960.

facts.text: Appellant Mohammad Serajuddin is the managing partner of Messrs. Serajuddin and Co., at No. 19A, British Indian Street and P-16, Bentinck Street, Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, Mohammad Serajuddin is the managing partner of Messrs. Serajuddin and Co., of No. 19A, British Indian Street and of p-16, Bentick Street, Calcutta.

facts.text: The firm carries on business as exporters of mineral ores and possesses some mines.

anchor.surface_text: The said firm carries on business as exporters of mineral ores, and also possesses some mines.

facts.text: Till April 1948, there was no export duty on manganese ore.

anchor.surface_text: The business of the appellant involved the export of manganese ore. Till April, 1948, there was numberexport duty on manganese ore.

facts.text: On April 19, 1948, export duty at ad valorem rates was imposed on manganese ore.

anchor.surface_text: On April 19, 1948, export duty at ad valorem rates was imposed on manganese ore.

facts.text: Export duty on manganese ore was withdrawn in August 1954.

anchor.surface_text: This was withdrawn in August, 1954, but was re-imposed in September, 1956

facts.text: Export duty on manganese ore was re-imposed in September 1956.

anchor.surface_text: This was withdrawn in August, 1954, but was re-imposed in September, 1956 and was withdrawn again in November, 1958.

facts.text: Export duty on manganese ore was withdrawn again in November 1958.

anchor.surface_text: re-imposed in September, 1956 and was withdrawn again in November, 1958. During this period, the appellant exported manganese ore,

facts.text: Appellant exported manganese ore during the period of duty impositions.

anchor.surface_text: During this period, the appellant exported manganese ore, among other mineral ores.

facts.text: On November 28, 1959, application made under s.172 Sea Customs Act to Chief Presidency Magistrate, Calcutta for search warrants on two premises.

anchor.surface_text: On November 28, 1959, an application was made under s. 172 of the Sea Customs Act to the Chief Presidency Magistrate, Calcutta requesting that warrants be issued to search the two premises already mentioned,

facts.text: Allegation: documents relating to illegal exportation of dutiable goods secreted in premises.

anchor.surface_text: on the allegation that documents relating to and companynected with illegal exportation of dutiable goods which were actually exported in companytravention of the Sea Customs Act were secreted in the above premises.

facts.text: Chief Presidency Magistrate issued two warrants returnable on December 5, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The Chief Presidency Magistrate issued two warrants returnable on December 5, 1959.

facts.text: Time for return of warrants extended to December 15, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently, time for return was extended to December 15, 1959.

facts.text: On December 12, 1959, Chief Presidency Magistrate limited search to documents relating to manganese ore and fixed time of day for search.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the search was carried with somewhat undue zest, and the Chief Presidency Magistrate, on December 12, 1959, limited the search to documents relating to manganese ore and also fixed the time of the day during which the search companyld be made.

facts.text: Appellant made unsuccessful applications for withdrawal of search warrants.

anchor.surface_text: Meanwhile, applications for withdrawal of the search warrants were unsuccessfully made by the appellant,

facts.text: Customs authorities seized 959 documents, registers, books etc.

anchor.surface_text: and, in the end, the Customs authorities seized 959 documents, registers, books, etc.

facts.text: On December 15, 1959, Customs applied for permission to retain documents for scrutiny.

anchor.surface_text: The Customs authorities wished to retain these documents in their own custody for the purpose of scrutiny, and on December 15, 1959, an application was made to obtain this permission.

facts.text: On December 15, 1959, appellant applied for return of unconnected documents and court custody of others.

anchor.surface_text: On the same day, the appellant also applied for return of documents unconnected with the export of manganese ore and for retention of the remaining documents in the, custody of the Court.

facts.text: Chief Presidency Magistrate ordered documents kept in court custody with inspection facilities for Customs.

anchor.surface_text: The Chief Presidency Magistrate passed an order the same day that the documents would be kept in the custody of the Court and the Customs authorities would be given facilities to inspect them in the Court premises.

facts.text: Inspection commenced on December 17, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: This inspection companymenced on December 17, 1959.

facts.text: Magistrate extended time for inspection till April 9, 1960, declined requests for return or handover.

anchor.surface_text: Suffice it to say that the Magistrate declined both the requests, and extended time for inspection till April 9, 1960.

facts.text: On February 6, 1960, Customs filed application for custody and facilities, dismissed same day.

anchor.surface_text: On February 6, 1960, the Customs authorities filed a last application for getting custody of the documents and for certain facilities for proper inspection in secrecy, if the inspection was to be done in the Court premises. This application was summarily dismissed by the Magistrate the same day.

facts.text: Customs authorities filed revision application in Calcutta High Court against Magistrate's order.

anchor.surface_text: Against the order of the Magistrate, an application for revision was filed by the Customs authorities in the Calcutta High Court.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court disposed of revision on July 1, 1960, ordered handover of documents except 63 to Customs within 3 months.

anchor.surface_text: The application in revision was disposed of on July 1, 1960 by the High Court, and it is that order which is appealed against, with certificate. The High Court... ordered that all the documents  bar 63 documents  should at once be handed over to the Customs authorities... within three months

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal by certificate under Art. 134(1)(c) of Constitution granted by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is by certificate under Art. 134  1   c  of the Constitution granted by the High Court of Calcutta against its judgment and other dated July 1, 1960.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Magistrate correct in retaining custody of seized documents.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the view expressed by Sen, J., is companyrect. In view of what we have said above, it is clear that the Magistrates order that the 959 documents, which were seized, should remain in his custody

facts.text: Supreme Court set aside High Court order for handing over documents to Customs.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, we must discharge the order of the learned Judge that the documents be handed over to the Customs authorities.

facts.text: Supreme Court directed facilities for inspection: separate room, after hours, presence of court official, 4 months period.

anchor.surface_text: The Magistrate is right in keeping these documents in his immedi- ate custody but we must direct that due facilities for inspection should be afforded to the Customs authorities in the shape of a separate room and suitable furuiture and time extended beyond the ordinary Court hours... a period of four months from the date this order reaches the Magistrate should prove enough.
This appeal is by certificate under Art. 134  1   c  of the Constitution granted by the High Court

arguments.claim: Magistrate has discretion pre-issue to check if belief genuine or mala fides

anchor.surface_text: the magistrate, in issuing the search warrant, acts judicially, and may examine whether the belief is really entertained by the Customs Officer or number, or whether there is any mala fide action. Except for these two matters, the magistrate has numberother discretion.

holdings.text: Search warrants issued under s.172 of the Sea Customs Act shall be executed in the same way and shall have the same effect as search warrants under the Criminal Procedure Code, including the requirement to produce seized goods or documents before the issuing Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: The second paragraph of s. 172 of the Sea Customs Act, which applies the Criminal Procedure Code, says that the warrant shall be executed in the same way and shall have the same effect as a search warrant issued under the Criminal Procedure Code. The execution of a warrant is one thing, and its effect is another. In talking of the effect, s. 172 of the Sea Customs Act intends to apply not only the Criminal Procedure Code but also the forms prescribed, and if the form says that the goods or documents should be produced before the Magistrate

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of s.172 second paragraph applying CrPC execution and effect, including prescribed forms requiring production before Magistrate.

holdings.text: A Magistrate issuing a search warrant under s.172 retains ultimate control and responsibility over its execution and the custody of seized documents to prevent abuse or harassment.

anchor.surface_text: A Magistrate, who issues a search warrant, is entitled to see that his warrant is not abused, and has been properly executed. In a suitable case, of course, a Magistrate may amend the warrant dispensing with the production of the goods or documents before him. That, however, would be in a clear case only but if the Magistrate so desires, he need not amend the form, and may keep the control of the goods or documents in himself.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive reading to ensure no abuse of warrant; Magistrate decides custody post-production; follows Sen J.

holdings.text: Customs authorities are not entitled to automatic custody of documents seized under s.172 warrant; they must produce them before the Magistrate who decides custody.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the view expressed by Sen, J., is correct. In view of what we have said above, it is clear that the Magistrates order that the 959 documents, which were seized, should remain in his custody and be scrutinised in his Court, was also correct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adopts Sen J's view; s.172 incorporates CrPC effect requiring production and Magistrate control over custody.

holdings.text: In issuing s.172 warrant, Magistrate acts judicially, guided primarily by Customs officer's stated belief but may check if belief genuine or action mala fide; no broader discretion.

anchor.surface_text: There can be no doubt also that unlike s. 96, the magistrate is to be guided by the belief on the Customs authorities, though he may prevent undue harassment in cases, where it can be seen that the belief is not entertained by the Customs officer or his action is mala fide. The Magistrate is certainly entitled to satisfy himself about the belief of the Customs Officer

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual distinction from CrPC s.96 (no 'court reason to believe'); limited judicial check on officer's belief.

holdings.text: Chief Presidency Magistrate's order retaining custody was correct, but facilities for Customs inspection were inadequate.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, though the learned Magistrate was legally right in retaining control over the documents seized, he was unduly narrow in his view in affording facilities for inspection and scrutiny.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Custody correct per law, but balance Customs' statutory duties requiring better inspection facilities.

holdings.text: High Court order handing over seized documents (except 63) to Customs authorities is set aside; documents remain in Magistrate's custody with enhanced inspection facilities.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, we must discharge the order of the learned Judge that the documents be handed over to the Customs authorities.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court erred on custody entitlement; Magistrate retains per s.172/CrPC; direct specific facilities.

holdings.text: Magistrate to provide Customs facilities: separate room, suitable furniture, inspection beyond court hours, court official presence, privacy for questioning, 4 months period.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Practical directions to enable effective scrutiny while retaining judicial control; accommodates both parties.

precedents.citation: Calcutta Motor Cycle Co. v. Collector of Customs  1

anchor.surface_text: In an unreported case of the Calcutta High Court, Calcutta Motor Cycle Co. v. Collector of Customs  1 , Debabrata Mookerjee, J., has held that search warrants must be issued, when the Customs Officer states his belief etc., and the Magistrate is number required to form his own opinion. He has further held that warrants issued under s. 172 are number impressed with all the characteristics and features of a warrant under s. 96 of the Criminal Procedure Code, and that the form of the warrant prescribed under the Code can be suitably changed under s. 555 of the Criminal Procedure Code. Unfortunately, the judgment of Mookerjee, J., was number produced before us, and the above is a summary made in the judgment under appeal.

precedents.case_name: Calcutta Motor Cycle Co. v. Collector of Customs
precedents.cited_proposition: Magistrate is not required to form his own opinion on Customs Officer's belief for issuing search warrant under s.172 Sea Customs Act; warrants not impressed with all characteristics of CrPC s.96 warrant; form can be changed under CrPC s.555

precedents.citation: Calcutta Motor Cycle Co. v. Collector of Customs  2

anchor.surface_text: In Calcutta Motor Cycle Co. v. Collector of Customs  2 , Sinha, J., dealt with the matter under Art. 226 of the Constitution. The view of Sinha, J., was upheld by the Division Bench in Collector of Customs v. Calcutta Motor Cycle Co.  1 . It is held in that case that a general seach warrant without specifying the goods or documents is a good warrant, and that the warrant for search implies the power to seize goods and documents. Sinha, J. also observes obiter that the goods or documents seized as a result of the search need number be produced before the Magistrate, and may be retained by the Customs authorities, and, further, that the warrant should be suitably amended enable the Customs authorities number only to search for goods or documents but also to seize them.

precedents.case_name: Calcutta Motor Cycle Co. v. Collector of Customs
precedents.cited_proposition: General search warrant without specifying goods/documents is valid; implies power to seize; obiter: seized goods/documents need not be produced before Magistrate, can be retained by Customs; warrant should be amended for seizure power

precedents.citation: Collector of Customs v. Calcutta Motor Cycle Co.  1

anchor.surface_text: The view of Sinha, J., was upheld by the Division Bench in Collector of Customs v. Calcutta Motor Cycle Co.  1 . It is held in that case that a general seach warrant without specifying the goods or documents is a good warrant, and that the warrant for search implies the power to seize goods and documents.

precedents.case_name: Collector of Customs v. Calcutta Motor Cycle Co.
precedents.cited_proposition: Upholding Sinha J: general search warrant valid, implies seizure power

anchor.surface_text: In S. K. Sribastava v. Gananand  2 , Sen, J., dissent from the observations of Sinha, J., and holds that when goods or documents are seized in execution of a search warrant, the ultimate disposal of the books and papers must be unde the Magistrates order, and that there is numberhing in the Sea Customsd Act to show that the Customs-collector is the final authority to dispose of the papers and books. he also does number accept the companytention that, as there is numberpending proceeding in the Court, the production of the goods and documents seized is number necessary before the Court. He further holds that the Magistrate has the power to insist that the inspection shall be companypleted within a reasonable time, and papers and books number required for the purpose of the case are returned promptly to the party. At p. 1078, the learned Judge observes After seizure by the police in execution of the search warrant, the goods and documents must numbermally be produced before the companyrt issuing the search warrant.

precedents.cited_proposition: Seized goods/documents under search warrant disposed under Magistrate's order; Customs Collector not final authority; must produce before court issuing warrant; Magistrate can fix reasonable time for inspection and return unneeded items
precedents.cited_holding: After seizure by the police in execution of the search warrant, the goods and documents must normally be produced before the court issuing the search warrant.

precedents.citation: Clarke v. Brojendra Kishore Roy Choudhury  1

anchor.surface_text: The pendency of a proceeding before a magistrate as a condition precedent to the issue of a warrant is numberlonger a matter for consideration, after the decision of the Privy Council in Clarke v. Brojendra Kishore Roy Choudhury  1 . A Magistrate thus has jurisdiction the moment an application for warrant is made before him, and proceedings on that application can be said to have started under the Code.

precedents.case_name: Clarke v. Brojendra Kishore Roy Choudhury
precedents.cited_proposition: Pendency of a proceeding before magistrate is not a condition precedent to issue of search warrant

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, set aside the order for the handing over of the documents to the Customs authorities, and make a direction for the disposal of the records, as stated abo

outcome.relief_summary: Set aside the Calcutta High Court's order directing handover of seized documents (except 63) to Customs authorities; upheld Chief Presidency Magistrate's order retaining custody of documents in court but directed provision of adequate facilities for inspection and scrutiny by Customs authorities.
directions: Documents to remain in immediate custody of the Chief Presidency Magistrate
Afford due facilities for inspection: separate room and suitable furniture
Permit inspection beyond ordinary Court hours
Conduct inspection in presence of a Court official
Provide adequate privacy for questioning witnesses and informers
Complete inspection within four months from the date of this order reaching the Magistrate

anchor.surface_text: The second paragraph of s. 172 of the Sea Customs Act, which applies the Criminal Procedure Code, says that the warrant shall be executed in the same way and shall have the same effect as a search warrant issued under the Criminal Procedure Code. The execution of a warrant is one thing, and its effect is another. In talking of the effect, s. 172 of the Sea Customs Act intends to apply not only the Criminal Procedure Code but also the forms prescribed, and if the form says that the goods or documents should be produced before the Magistrate
We, therefore, set aside the order for the handing over of the documents to the Customs authorities, and make a direction for the disposal of the records, as stated abo

anchor.surface_text: A Magistrate, who issues a search warrant, is entitled to see that his warrant is not abused, and has been properly executed. In a suitable case, of course, a Magistrate may amend the warrant dispensing with the production of the goods or documents before him. That, however, would be in a clear case only but if the Magistrate so desires, he need not amend the form, and may keep the control of the goods or documents in himself.
We, therefore, set aside the order for the handing over of the documents to the Customs authorities, and make a direction for the disposal of the records, as stated abo

edges.explanation: h3 addresses i1 by denying Customs automatic custody entitlement

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the view expressed by Sen, J., is correct. In view of what we have said above, it is clear that the Magistrates order that the 959 documents, which were seized, should remain in his custody and be scrutinised in his Court, was also correct.
We, therefore, set aside the order for the handing over of the documents to the Customs authorities, and make a direction for the disposal of the records, as stated abo

anchor.surface_text: There can be no doubt also that unlike s. 96, the magistrate is to be guided by the belief on the Customs authorities, though he may prevent undue harassment in cases, where it can be seen that the belief is not entertained by the Customs officer or his action is mala fide. The Magistrate is certainly entitled to satisfy himself about the belief of the Customs Officer
We, therefore, set aside the order for the handing over of the documents to the Customs authorities, and make a direction for the disposal of the records, as stated abo

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, though the learned Magistrate was legally right in retaining control over the documents seized, he was unduly narrow in his view in affording facilities for inspection and scrutiny.
We, therefore, set aside the order for the handing over of the documents to the Customs authorities, and make a direction for the disposal of the records, as stated abo
